initial_reviews.review_title: Most Powerful CICD tool for handling all stages in pipeline with versatile programs
initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins is a CI/CD tool which is designed to provide continuous deployment, continuous integration, and continuous delivery also its the best integration tools in the market, It also supports many plugins. It is targeting users are developers and teams looking to automate parts of their software development process.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins requires considerably  more  setup and maintenance, potentially causing initial hurdles and also nitial interaction with Jenkins can be unnerving for beginners, due to its diverse nature.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins supports around 1500 plugins so it helped us a alot in our project allowing customization and integration with various tools and platforms. Also It works seamlessly across different operating systems and environments which benefited us because we have multiple flavours os operating systems in our project

initial_reviews.review_title: CI/CD with Jenkins: Master Tool for Automating Any DevOps Flow
initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Plugins : It support almost every important libtray out there, allowing every kind of integration with this tool.
Deployment Automation : I have worked for an operation team, we did automate the deployment and restart of application. Customer : 100 + and environment : 400+.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Being said that it is an open source technology, it never dissapointed in the features it provides. However, since we used Jenkins to automate  more than 1000+ instances, it slows down at times.
Jenkins UI is  lame.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins did solve the manual work, whcih  operation team used to perform, like restart of an application. and deployment of war and validation of the application.  It helped operation team to concentrate on more technical problems.

initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
1. Jenkins has lots of plugins that users like because they work well with different tools. Users can change Jenkins to fit their needs.

2. People think Jenkins is great for managing tasks like continuous integration and deployment, even for big projects.

3. Users love that they can customize Jenkins for their projects. Being able to adapt Jenkins is important for fitting in with how projects are developed.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins may not be suitable, for beginners as it has a bit of a learning curve. Its interface appears outdated. It can be resource intensive. Security concerns have been raised by some users. Working with plugins can pose challenges at times.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
As we work in an edtech company, it helps us to log in to the client environment in a few seconds providing a secured token for one-time login.
Additionally, It makes updates faster and prevents panic caused by deployment issues. It helps catch problems before customers notice.

initial_reviews.review_title: Jenkins(CI/CD):Continuous integration and Continuous Delivery in Software Development
initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
*Jenkins is open-source and it allows all users to use its every functionality through plugins without any rstrictions.
*Jenkins can integrate with many cloud providers like GCP and AWS .
*Jenkins support multiple operating systems, making it versatilee for use in different environments.
*Jenkins supports build and deployment tasks across multipe machines which helps organization to deploy all changes in one go .
*Jenkins is easy to set-up and configure with all type of machines and operating systems .

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
*Jenkins UI visually outdated and complex configurations may require a learning curve.
*Now github and gitlab also provide CI/CD with code hosting platform.
*For containerization technologies like kubernetes and docker it may lack of built-in support for this.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
I am a Devops engineer and i started with Jenkins in my begining of career and it helps me in some automation in :
*script building
*Docker image building pushing it to Container registry and pulling it for service new version update
*Runing multiple Dependent jobs my crone function
*Deploying every new line of code continuously
*Doing multiple installation by running a single script on multiple servers

Jenkins Helps a lot in my professional journey.

initial_reviews.review_title: I just love jenkins for my cicd pipeline
initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins is a great CI/CD tool because it is free of cost and available for all the platforms for eg Windows.Mac,Linux

1>it is open source so its very much secured

2>it is very easy to install and use Jenkins

3>it is Highly extensible with plugins

4>it Supports a wide range of languages and platforms

Here are some of the things I like most about Jenkins:

GitHub/Bitbucket integration: Jenkins can be easily integrated with GitHub/Bitbucket, making it easy to clone projects and build and deploy code from GitHub.

Scriptable: Jenkins can be scripted using Groovy,Shell which gives you the flexibility to automate complex tasks.

Parallel execution: Jenkins can execute build and deployment steps in parallel, which can significantly reduce the time it takes to deploy new code.

Tracking: Jenkins provides detailed tracking of builds and deployments, which can help you identify and troubleshoot problems quickly
I frequently use jenkins for my CICD deployment for SFCC and AWS.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
As its free tool so there is no specific commercial customer support for jenkins. So We need to rely on the Jenkins community for any issue We are facing in Jenkins. Configuring multi branch pipeline jobs are little bit complex in Jenkins.If multiple jobs running on the master node of the Jenkins it can be very slow and unresponsive. Many plugins are also not maintained so if we use old not compatible plugins,it can corrupt the jenkins node and jobs will dissapear from the view.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins is a very powerful and easy to use CICD tool for any kind of code deployment. And I am using currently jenkins for AWS and SFCC code deployment.
Creating a pipeline is very easy using the Jenkins UI and We can run several build parallely which eventually save our time.It has a very clean UI and dashboard.

initial_reviews.review_title: Jenkins: The DevOps Powerhouse - Best CI/CD tool I ever used
initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
What I appreciate most about Jenkins is its role in automating and simplifying the SDLC process. The flexibility it offers in creating scheduling, and CD/CD pipelines is remarkable.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
The maintenance of Jenkins can also be a concern. As pipelines become more complex and the number of jobs and ybuilds increases, the need for proper management and maintenance becomes more apparent. Ensui=ring that Jenkins remains performant and error-free requires ongoing attention, which can be time consuming.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
It automates the process of building code from source control repos such as Github, Gitlab, BitBueckt etc. This eliminates the need for manual compilation and helps ensure that builds are consistent and reproducible, it helps in continous integration and deployment, it is an open source software. It has extensive plug-in support.

Interface of Jenkins would be overwhelming for the newcomers.
Sometimes after pre pipeline passes it doesn't shows the corner green tick inplace of that it shows that the pipeline is still in progress.
More proper visulization of the  console to see the proper error of the broken pipeline.

Jenkins is a effecient platform where we can see that our code is properly build and deploy is done or not.It contains that latest changes in the history to make sure what changes were done. Jenkins have pre pipline which runs before merging the code and post pipeline after the merge .In Jenkins we can see all the scheduled build and deployments of the project and in case if the pipeline fails it have console where the error gets printed.

initial_reviews.review_title: Looking for CI/CD tool, use Jenkins
initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Its is an open-source tool, so it is free to use. it is relatively easy to set up and use, even for those with limited experience with CI/CD tools. its pipelines can also be defined in code, Its has more 1800 plugins, can be extended to handle almost any build, test, and deployment task imaginable.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
The vast plugin ecosystem, while offering flexibility, can also lead to configuration sprawl and complexity. Maintaining and troubleshooting these plugins can add to the burden. it can handle small and medium-sized projects well, it can struggle with scaling to large, complex deployments. maintenance overhead

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
I am using it to handle whole CI/CD for my organisation in less cost.

Jenkins can consume more server resources compare to modern CICD.

initial_reviews.review_title: An open source CI-CD server written in Java
initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins works on all platforms be it Windows, Mac or Linux.
Jenkins is opensource and hence free to use although we need a physical server to host it.
It provides tonnes of plugins to support build deployment and automation. Creating our own plugins is also easy. We can write custom plugins to integrate Jenkins with other tools, to add or modify builds and more.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins setup and configuration requires coding skills.
Jenkins is based on a single server architecture. It doesn't allow server to server federation which causes performance issues in largescale setup.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins server being hosted internally makes it a perfect choice because our teams working on sensitive projects are wary of sharing everything with a third party server that's hosted outside our premises. Jenkins allows us to run continuous integration on our own servers thereby giving us complete control.

initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
It is a very popular automation server that helps the team to improve the quality, speed and cost-effectiveness of the software development process. It is free, open-source, versatile, easy to use, scalable, and secure. It helps automate the testing process, build and deployment process, and task automation, otherwise to be done manually. Likable features: Jenkins pipelines, declarative pipelines, Jenkins jobs DSL.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
First thing: it can be complex to set up and configure due to its vast options/features. It is hungry for resources, i.e. it uses a lot of resources, which can be a problem for smaller projects. There is difficulty in troubleshooting if something goes wrong in Jenkings; there is no easy way to figure it out.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Mainly it automates manual tasks, such as building, testing and deploying software. It free up my team to focus on other tasks.
Since it is automated, errors can be eliminated. It provide a central place to view the status of the software development process.
Reduces cost

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
1. Jenkins has lots of plugins that users like because they work well with different tools. Users can change Jenkins to fit their needs.

2. People think Jenkins is great for managing tasks like continuous integration and deployment, even for big projects.

3. Users love that they can customize Jenkins for their projects. Being able to adapt Jenkins is important for fitting in with how projects are developed.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins may not be suitable, for beginners as it has a bit of a learning curve. Its interface appears outdated. It can be resource intensive. Security concerns have been raised by some users. Working with plugins can pose challenges at times.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
As we work in an edtech company, it helps us to log in to the client environment in a few seconds providing a secured token for one-time login.
Additionally, It makes updates faster and prevents panic caused by deployment issues. It helps catch problems before customers notice.

all_reviews.review_title: Jenkins(CI/CD):Continuous integration and Continuous Delivery in Software Development
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
*Jenkins is open-source and it allows all users to use its every functionality through plugins without any rstrictions.
*Jenkins can integrate with many cloud providers like GCP and AWS .
*Jenkins support multiple operating systems, making it versatilee for use in different environments.
*Jenkins supports build and deployment tasks across multipe machines which helps organization to deploy all changes in one go .
*Jenkins is easy to set-up and configure with all type of machines and operating systems .

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
*Jenkins UI visually outdated and complex configurations may require a learning curve.
*Now github and gitlab also provide CI/CD with code hosting platform.
*For containerization technologies like kubernetes and docker it may lack of built-in support for this.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
I am a Devops engineer and i started with Jenkins in my begining of career and it helps me in some automation in :
*script building
*Docker image building pushing it to Container registry and pulling it for service new version update
*Runing multiple Dependent jobs my crone function
*Deploying every new line of code continuously
*Doing multiple installation by running a single script on multiple servers

Jenkins Helps a lot in my professional journey.

all_reviews.review_title: I just love jenkins for my cicd pipeline
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins is a great CI/CD tool because it is free of cost and available for all the platforms for eg Windows.Mac,Linux

1>it is open source so its very much secured

2>it is very easy to install and use Jenkins

3>it is Highly extensible with plugins

4>it Supports a wide range of languages and platforms

Here are some of the things I like most about Jenkins:

GitHub/Bitbucket integration: Jenkins can be easily integrated with GitHub/Bitbucket, making it easy to clone projects and build and deploy code from GitHub.

Scriptable: Jenkins can be scripted using Groovy,Shell which gives you the flexibility to automate complex tasks.

Parallel execution: Jenkins can execute build and deployment steps in parallel, which can significantly reduce the time it takes to deploy new code.

Tracking: Jenkins provides detailed tracking of builds and deployments, which can help you identify and troubleshoot problems quickly
I frequently use jenkins for my CICD deployment for SFCC and AWS.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
As its free tool so there is no specific commercial customer support for jenkins. So We need to rely on the Jenkins community for any issue We are facing in Jenkins. Configuring multi branch pipeline jobs are little bit complex in Jenkins.If multiple jobs running on the master node of the Jenkins it can be very slow and unresponsive. Many plugins are also not maintained so if we use old not compatible plugins,it can corrupt the jenkins node and jobs will dissapear from the view.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins is a very powerful and easy to use CICD tool for any kind of code deployment. And I am using currently jenkins for AWS and SFCC code deployment.
Creating a pipeline is very easy using the Jenkins UI and We can run several build parallely which eventually save our time.It has a very clean UI and dashboard.

all_reviews.review_title: Jenkins: The DevOps Powerhouse - Best CI/CD tool I ever used
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
What I appreciate most about Jenkins is its role in automating and simplifying the SDLC process. The flexibility it offers in creating scheduling, and CD/CD pipelines is remarkable.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
The maintenance of Jenkins can also be a concern. As pipelines become more complex and the number of jobs and ybuilds increases, the need for proper management and maintenance becomes more apparent. Ensui=ring that Jenkins remains performant and error-free requires ongoing attention, which can be time consuming.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
It automates the process of building code from source control repos such as Github, Gitlab, BitBueckt etc. This eliminates the need for manual compilation and helps ensure that builds are consistent and reproducible, it helps in continous integration and deployment, it is an open source software. It has extensive plug-in support.

all_reviews.review_title: Looking for CI/CD tool, use Jenkins
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Its is an open-source tool, so it is free to use. it is relatively easy to set up and use, even for those with limited experience with CI/CD tools. its pipelines can also be defined in code, Its has more 1800 plugins, can be extended to handle almost any build, test, and deployment task imaginable.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
The vast plugin ecosystem, while offering flexibility, can also lead to configuration sprawl and complexity. Maintaining and troubleshooting these plugins can add to the burden. it can handle small and medium-sized projects well, it can struggle with scaling to large, complex deployments. maintenance overhead

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
I am using it to handle whole CI/CD for my organisation in less cost.

all_reviews.review_title: An open source CI-CD server written in Java
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins works on all platforms be it Windows, Mac or Linux.
Jenkins is opensource and hence free to use although we need a physical server to host it.
It provides tonnes of plugins to support build deployment and automation. Creating our own plugins is also easy. We can write custom plugins to integrate Jenkins with other tools, to add or modify builds and more.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins setup and configuration requires coding skills.
Jenkins is based on a single server architecture. It doesn't allow server to server federation which causes performance issues in largescale setup.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins server being hosted internally makes it a perfect choice because our teams working on sensitive projects are wary of sharing everything with a third party server that's hosted outside our premises. Jenkins allows us to run continuous integration on our own servers thereby giving us complete control.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
It is a very popular automation server that helps the team to improve the quality, speed and cost-effectiveness of the software development process. It is free, open-source, versatile, easy to use, scalable, and secure. It helps automate the testing process, build and deployment process, and task automation, otherwise to be done manually. Likable features: Jenkins pipelines, declarative pipelines, Jenkins jobs DSL.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
First thing: it can be complex to set up and configure due to its vast options/features. It is hungry for resources, i.e. it uses a lot of resources, which can be a problem for smaller projects. There is difficulty in troubleshooting if something goes wrong in Jenkings; there is no easy way to figure it out.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Mainly it automates manual tasks, such as building, testing and deploying software. It free up my team to focus on other tasks.
Since it is automated, errors can be eliminated. It provide a central place to view the status of the software development process.
Reduces cost

all_reviews.review_title: Most efficient and reliable tool for build and test code using pipeline
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins is a very easy to setup tool to integrate and deploy software products. I like the way it does unit and integration tests on the code before creating a deployment package. It is very easy from Jenkins to publish snapshot/releases in to different repositories such as Nexus, AWS ECR, etc

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins can add a feature to not allow pipeline building without user login for security purposes. Which is the only change I want to see.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins is solving the problem of releasing software by providing features to build code by doing unit and integration tests. It is very easy for jenkins to do hard versioning of the code and release the build and snapshot the next version. At the same time using an automation pipeline it also publishes the build into different repos like Nexus and AWS ECR.

It is very easy from Jenkins to publish snapshot/releases in to different repositories such as Nexus, AWS ECR, etc

review_question_answers.question: What do you dislike about Jenkins?

Jenkins is highly scalable and supports a plethora of plugins & integration.

all_reviews.review_title: Easy to setup best CI/CD Automation
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Being an open-source automation tool with a large and active community. It provides a vast number of plugins and integrations, allowing users to extend its functionality to meet their specific needs.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Managing and maintaining a Jenkins installation requires ongoing effort and expertise. We have to handle plugin updates, security patches, and server maintenance to ensure smooth operation. It is time-consuming, especially for larger installations or organisations like us with complex setups.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Manually building and testing software can be time-consuming and prone to errors. It automates the build, test, and deployment processes, reducing manual effort and minimising the risk of human errors. It saves time and improves software quality. It allows easy scalability by distributing builds across multiple nodes or agents.

all_reviews.review_title: Jenkins: All-rounder for your CICD needs
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
1: It is highly customisable and flexible, allowing users to configure it to meet their requirements and workflows.
2:  Jenkins has a vast and active community of users and developers who contribute to its development and provide support through forums, mailing lists, and other channels.
3: Jenkins is designed for automation, which helps automate several repetitive operations throughout the software development process.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
I've been using Jenkins as my primary tool, and it has the following concerns:
1:It have performance concerns, mainly when dealing with big, sophisticated builds or pipelines.
2:its built-in capabilities are very restricted compared to other CI/CD solutions; many critical functions require installing third-party plugins.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
1: Jenkins can automate software application development, testing, and deployment. It may interface with various tools and technologies used in the software development process, such as source control systems, build tools, and testing frameworks. This automation saves time and minimises the chance of mistakes, making the development process more efficient and dependable.
In my case, we had a web application to deploy to a production environment. With Jenkins, we automated this process by setting up a pipeline that consists of several stages, including building the application, running tests, and deploying it to the production environment.
Also, Jenkins runs a series of automated tests on the application to ensure it functions correctly. These tests include unit tests, integration tests, and acceptance tests. If any of the tests fail, Jenkins will notify the development team via email or a messaging app, allowing them to address any issues quickly.
So with the help of Jenkins, we were able to automate the whole process of deployment.

all_reviews.review_title: Streamlining Your Software Development with Jenkins
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
One of the best things about Jenkins is its ability to automate the software development process. With Jenkins, you can set up automated builds, tests, and deployments for your software, which can save a lot of time and effort. This helps ensure that your code is reliable, stable, and free of bugs before it's released.

Jenkins also offers a wide range of plugins, which can help integrate various tools and technologies into your software development workflow. This means that you can customize Jenkins to fit the specific needs of your project and team, making it a highly flexible and versatile tool.

Finally, Jenkins has a large and active community of users and contributors, which means that it's constantly being updated and improved. This community provides support, documentation, and a wealth of resources, making it easier for developers to get up and running with Jenkins quickly and efficiently.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
One of the potential drawbacks of Jenkins is that it can be complex to set up and configure, especially for teams that are new to continuous integration and deployment. While Jenkins offers a wide range of customization options, this can also make it more difficult to use and manage, particularly for small teams with limited resources.

Another potential challenge with Jenkins is that it can require a significant amount of server resources, which can make it difficult to run on lower-end hardware or in resource-constrained environments. This can result in longer build times and slower performance, which can be frustrating for developers.

Finally, while Jenkins offers a wide range of plugins and integrations, managing these plugins and ensuring that they are up-to-date can be time-consuming and challenging. This can lead to compatibility issues and other problems that can slow down the software development process.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
One of the primary problems that Jenkins solves is the challenge of automating the software development process. Building, testing, and deploying software can be time-consuming and error-prone when done manually, which can lead to delays, errors, and reduced productivity. Jenkins automates these processes, enabling teams to test and deploy code changes more quickly and reliably, with fewer errors.

Jenkins also helps solve the problem of managing complex development workflows. With Jenkins, developers can create pipelines that automatically build, test, and deploy software, coordinating multiple stages and environments. This helps ensure that code changes are tested thoroughly before being released, which can reduce the risk of bugs and errors.

Jenkins is an old software but the mantainers release patches and upgrades really frequently. There are literally thousands plugins to interact/integrate with other tools, like Kubernetes, VCS, AWS services and so on.
It is a really flexible software which allows you to perform whatever task you need to execute.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?

all_reviews.review_title: Jenkins: The Premier Source Solution for Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment Pipelines
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins is a premier open-source tool that is widely used to build and manage CI/CD pipelines. The powerful automation capabilities of Jenkins have transformed the way organizations manage their software development life cycle. At our organization, Jenkins plays a crucial role in our deployment pipeline by automating various tasks such as code testing, integration and deployment. One of the key features of Jenkins is its ability to provide instant notifications in case of any job failures. The notifications include detailed information about the reasons behind the failure, allowing teams to quickly resolve the issues and get back on track. Overall, Jenkins is a reliable and efficient tool that has streamlined our software development process and enabled us to deliver better quality products to our customers.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins is a highly convenient tool for building and managing CI/CD pipelines, with few major drawbacks. However, there is room for improvement in terms of its user interface. While the current interface is functional, a more intuitive and streamlined design would enhance the user experience. One issue that has been noticed is that the UI sometimes gives errors when modifying jobs, which can be frustrating for users. Improving the user interface would further solidify Jenkins' position as a leading tool in the industry and make it even more user-friendly. Nevertheless, the benefits of using Jenkins outweigh these minor limitations and it remains a top choice for many organizations.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins has proven to be a valuable asset for organizations looking to streamline their software deployment process. With Jenkins, deployment time is significantly reduced as it allows for the integration of various deployment and testing suites directly into the build process. One of the key advantages of Jenkins is that it is open-source, providing organizations with the flexibility and cost savings they need to achieve their goals. Additionally, the tool's ability to provide insightful information in case of job failures helps developers quickly identify and resolve issues. The versatility of Jenkins is further enhanced by its customizable nature and the availability of various plugins, such as SonarQube, that allow organizations to tailor the tool to their specific needs. Overall, Jenkins is a reliable and efficient tool that has become an indispensable part of many organizations' software development process.

all_reviews.review_title: Using it for the past 10 years and it's the perfect CI/CD tool for all our customers
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
1. Opensource! What else can be better? Being an open-source tool leads to a very wide network and answers on the internet, for most of the project cases that you will meet.
2. It can almost automate everything, Jenkins scripts, plugins, running Linux/Windows batch files, and deploying to artifacts or any cloud space.
3.  I don't think there are any missing plugins so far, it's been enhanced over the years that Jenkins now supports almost all third-party plugins.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
1. The documentation of the plugins sometimes is very poor (This is expected with open source free plugins, but this leads to either not wanting to use it or you can not using it in a proper way).
2. I personally don't like the UI, I think it could be much better.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
1. Any scale of customer project that needs continuous integration, continuous testing, running automation scripts, and generating reports.
2. Daily/Overnight test cases for your project.

all_reviews.review_title: Streamlining Continuous Integration and Delivery with Jenkins
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
1)Easy installation and setup.
2)Large community and plugin ecosystem.
3)Customizable and extensible for different use cases.
4)Supports various platforms and languages.
5)Provides automation and continuous integration/continuous delivery (CI/CD) pipeline capabilities.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
1)Steep learning curve for beginners.
2)User interface can be outdated and difficult to navigate.
3)Maintenance and configuration can be time-consuming.
4)Limited documentation for advanced use cases.
5)Can have security vulnerabilities if not configured properly.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins simplifies the process of continuous integration and deployment, enabling developers to automate testing and delivery processes, resulting in faster and more reliable software releases.

all_reviews.review_title: Excellent tool for build and deployment
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
It is very easy to integrate the tool with version control softwares such as TFVC, TF GIT and many more. It has a major role in continuous integration and continuous deployment in production.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Troubleshooting UI can be improved since it is a lot of cumbersome to just find out the error when a job is run. So the area of improvement would be the overall user interface according to me.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
It is basically an automation server. We can configure Jenkins to run a seed job or with the help of triggers we can run a pipeline as and when a certain condition is met. It is also a very good alternative for MSBuild tool. All in all it is used to run a certain sequence of steps on server on its own without any manual intervention which will save a lot of manual effort and time at the same time.

all_reviews.review_title: Perfect tool for CI/CD and automation
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins is open source and is among the powerful CI/CD tools available in the market. What makes it more famous is its free and has a huge plugin base using which one can connect or integrate with most of the available tools. I have been using Jenkins for deploying java binaries in server which usually goes through a series of building, analysis, security checks and testing phases. The plugins available in Jenkins market are easy to install and connect with other tools. Its like if someone needs to automate something, that particular kind of plugin is most likely to be available in the marketplace. It's that easy to work with Jenkins.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
I have come across some other vendor CI/CD tools as well, but I have never found so well build and so feature-rich CI/CD tool like Jenkins. I havent find any downside of Jenkins so far. The UI can be a little more intuitive like the current available CI/CD tools , that is what I can say.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
I will definitely recommend using Jenkins as it is very easy to learn and implement. It doesn't need much infrastructure to implement and doesn't need heavy software to install on multiple machines.  Its inexpensive and has a huge community and marketplace and most importantly it reduces time and effort of automation and delivery and thereby increasing the throughput and productivity of the project.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Currently we are using Jenkins for deployment purpose in our project which includes Git cloning, building, static code analysis, uploading in JFrog repository, building docker images, deploying in kubernates ,  and running unit test cases. So it actually eliminates all the manual labour that would need to perform all these tasks. It saves time and effort. Apart from that QA team uses it to perform automation testing, API testing using Jenkins. The chart and graph facility of Jenkins is cherry on the cake that helps to analyze the success and failure rates of the test cases. It reduces much time and effort in performing every time testing before production deployment.

Also the report generated through Jenkins is very easy to interpret.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins is such a widely used solution nowadays that I feel people have forgotten it's downsides. Same is the case with me as well but if I have to name one I would say that the console logging can be designed in a better way for troubleshooting the errors.

all_reviews.review_title: Jenkins is a very good tool for CI and CD
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
1. Jenkins is very easy to set up and configure.
2. It has a very good number of plugins that allows user/administrator to install only the needed plugins (or feature). In other words, it does not come with a bulky installer.
3. Jenkins server can be set up on Linux machines and Windows machines.
4. Upgrade process for the Jenkins server is very easy.
5. It does not have a database. All the configurations are stored in the XML file. So administrators can edit XML files directly from the file system too. Sometimes that is very easy to spread the change across multiple Jenkins projects (instead of doing one by one from UI).
6. It's free.
7. Jenkins supports different types of source control repositories like SVN, Git, etc. The developer can set different triggers after making changes in the codes
8.  It is very easy to find out the errors in the Jenkins. The developer can easily check the bug and resolve it.
9. Jenkins has very large support in the industry. The community has more than 1000000 users all over the world, and it was officially published in 2011.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
1. You will need to install a lot of plugins. You can't find even basic things without plug-ins.
2. Sometimes plugin upgrade requires Jenkins to upgrade and it can be become painful at times.
3. All plug-ins are not compatible with the declarative pipeline syntax.
Managing of Jenkins dashboard is hard when we have too many jobs to be executed.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
It's a great product and has a lot to offer even though it comes for free.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
1. It definitely helped us in creating and growing our build system with automation.
2. Most of the other benefits I already mentioned above in what I liked about Jenkins.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
We are using Jenkins for building and deploying the application running on-prem or in the cloud. One of the best things about Jenkins is that we can easily install it by using the docker image. For building the application we are using Docker-based nodes triggers only during the requirement, this saves lots of money as we run the resources only during the requirement. We can easily integrate SonarQube, Jococo and CheckMarks to enable secure builds.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
It's a nice tool but UI is very outdated. Adding the BlueOcean plugin can improve the UI but there will be no improvement in the functionality. It's good if we need a pipeline for local development but the cloud, it's not recommended due to high management and hosting costs.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
We used it for small projects for creating the Docker and react builds. We were easily able to do it as we configured custom nodes for different stages of the pipeline like test, scan, build and deploy.

all_reviews.review_title: One Of The Best CI/CD Tools
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins has support for multiple languages. Being an open-source tool, it has a huge community for support, and multiple plugins are present for all our day-to-day needs, like sending email after completion of Jenkins job, which makes it one of the best CI/CD tools in the market. Also, due to its open-source nature, anyone can quickly learn it and perform hands-on before going for an enterprise version.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins GUI is not that much user-friendly as compared to Bamboo for CI/CD where we can easily integerate our code base on bitbucket and create releses, deploy.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
We are using Jenkins for building and deploying our applications based on java, nodejs, reactjs etc. Also, we are using Jenkins for the execution of our test automation suites(Regression Test, Sanity Test etc). We have scheduled jobs for QA automation to help us find bugs on time.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
This automation server this an essential tool for today's development office. Its plethora of features, varying from simple tasks (like compilation and deployment)  to more complex ones, made the programmer's life easier and free of repetitive tasks. Once you try this server on your development life cycle, it's hard to go back and manually do CI/CD.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
There is some learning curve from the newcomer that is not avoidable, intrinsic to the server management and its features, that make a little tricky a similar to the steps make on a local or manual CI/CD cycle. Some options, although well explained, have others that are ratter scarsed explained in its GUI, but with a google search, some or all doubts are gone.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
Consider delegate or have a DevOps role for administration of the server. This role focuses on value options for the CI/CD of the company's clients in the long term, and the programmer's life will turn into a productive and focused day, worry-free.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
The primary benefit of adopting this server is the standardization of the deployment cycle and all of these steps. All of the everyday tasks in this area have been ripped off our programmer's shoulders, with a time reduction involved that allows them to make value proposals for the company. If you are running a software development company, take this into account.

all_reviews.review_title: One of the most, if not THE most efficient automation servers/software on the market
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins provides a clean and efficient GUI to view the builds and branches of code that create your overall product. Jenkins also provides great history on the build and where certain errors may be occuring and how to narrow down what occurred that caused the error.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
The user has to have very in-depth knowledge on what is included in a builds and what the builds are being used for to have any idea on how to use Jenkins. Not only this, there is a lack of ability to record information other than tags on the build, so new updates are not known unless a version control like GIT is used in tandem.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins helps to narrow down on errors in a much more efficient manner, as well as being able to call to the most recent successful build so that testing and continuous development can work in tandem and smoothly.

all_reviews.review_title: You can't go wrong with Jenkins
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins is the standard CI/CD solution that everyone starts from. It is versatile, has an LTS version and a multitude of plugins suitable for every imaginable use case.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Plugin hell.  It is very easy to get carried away and install each and every plugin that looks suitable for a use case and forget it installed, even when not using it. If you lack the discipline to work with very few plugins, you end up with a system with so many interdependencies that no upgrade is possible, and in the end, you are forced to abandon it due to complexity.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
Jenkins is where you start your CI/CD journey from. If you make an effort to learn Groovy, it may be where you stay anyways. But even if you do not want to stay with Jenkins, it is this software and its capabilities that define the bar that every other CI/CD software needs to pass to be seriously considered by anyone. And that is why it is worth it to work with Jenkins.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins is used for building and testing software primarily. However, you can "subvert" it into a glorified cron scheduler that can run complex jobs and not necessarily shell or other scripts. You can also use it as a deployment system where you can program the logic of the deployment the exact way you want it. Finally, if you are up for the task, you can even use the agents it provides for remote execution for network/host management.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?

all_reviews.review_title: Jenkins: Powerful Opensource Continuous Integration tool
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
- It has got plugin for almost every tool used across the software industry.

- It is highly customizable.

- It has a Large community, A big active user base and new functionalities are added frequently.

- It's secure even it's opensource, security patches are also released frequently.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
- We have only community support so sometimes it can be problematic to troubleshoot or fix issues.

- Most of the plugins are developed and managed by opensource contributors so we've to relay on the mercy of collaborators or to develop our own.

- Sometimes it's very hard to troubleshoot the issues due to improper error handling in plugins.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
UI is improved but if its UI gets modernized than it will be great or if BlueOcean like view can be replicated in settings and other pages.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
We're using Jenkins as a CI tool, We are administrating and managing it for a large number of teams.

Its stable and requires very less maintenance.

Easy to upgrade to a newer version.

Feature and functionality wise It's far better than all other enterprise CI tools.

By using Jenkins we're saving significant amount of money

all_reviews.review_title: Perfect example of Old is Gold !!
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
- A large number of plugins are supported in Jenkins.
- Easy to back up & restore , since jobs,plugins,nodes are present in Jenkins Home folder.
- Migration of settings has become easier with the advent of "Configuration As Code" plugin.
- Supports dynamic node configuration.
- Jenkinsfile integration with Gitlab.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
- Plugins update are hard to catch and becomes complicated when they are integrated into existing pipelines.
- Webhook configuration is also tricky.
- Node related error messages are not so straight forward and interpretation becomes difficult.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
Jenkins is very favorable to manage & use.
It can solve all your Integration and deployment issues.
If you do not want to spend much , then opt for open source Jenkins. It also provides most of the features.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
--  Jenkins is used as a Continuous Integration tool in our Organization.
-   Jenkins uses code from Gitlab to build  applications like maven , npm , docker etc.
-   After creating the binaries, jenkins pushes them to the artifactory or nexus repositories.
-   Post the build, jenkins sends the success/failure mail & build report to the team members.
-   We are now configuring docker slaves with our jenkins.
-  We have also integrated white source, blackduck & checkmarx with our jenkins for security scans.

all_reviews.review_title: Great automation platform for experienced IT engineers
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins has almost every use case you could imagine on your stacks. If any integration is missing, you may extend a script. Jenkins is the de-facto open-source automation technology, so chances that you find the right way are pretty broad.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Is hard to keep update on fixes and security patches, upgrades (even on docker containers) are really painful. Inbound agents are tricky to configure, and in general you need vast experience on several distributed IT subjects as: linux, groovy, java, docker, networks, reverse proxies and any tech you want to integrate.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
always use pipelines, groovy may be tricky, frustrating and weird at first, but you will be on fire once you make your build and deploy patterns. Always version your configs, try to backup (at least) as often as you upgrade the instance, use oidc for auth/authz, separate preprod/prod stages with webhooks.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Forget any manual steps or custom scripts; Jenkins allows batch automation, standardized scripting, fine grained permission segregation, openid-connect authentication, and authorization.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
It is one of the most used CI/CD tools as it supports the complete development life cycle of software. We can continuously integrate by creating different pipelines so that that process will get automated. Starting from build, test, documentation, deployment, and other stages can be automated using pipelines. Jenkins has a lot of plugins that make it easier to configure and customize as per requirement. We can create different test scripts in various suites by giving suite and script names in the YAML file. It has radiator features to monitor your test scripts. You can schedule and frequency of your pipeline easily. You can pull the changes easily from GitLab.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Nothing is there that I dislike. But sometimes, scripts are not able to run when more scripts are triggered at a time.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
In our team, we are using Jenkins to build and test our automation scripts. We have created a different pipeline for various stages and scheduled those as per our timing.
We have configured a radiator for a different suite, and there we have our automation scripts. We can track our script's status by customizing its color. We can analyze our failed scripts by analyzing allure/fitness reports integrated with them. We can give access and permission as per their role to perform a particular action. And many more benefits are there.

all_reviews.review_title: Application deployment made easy with this software
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins play a major role in facilitating the continuous deployment and continuous delivery of the application. It helps in reducing the effort of the developers by deploying the application through a scheduled pipeline. The learning curve is very smooth and very few parameters are required to automate the deployment. Test cases can also be integrated with the pipeline which prevents the breaking of any existing functionality. The code coverage was also part of the pipeline, which brought everything under one roof. Once the pipeline is set up, it can be used multiple times to deeply various branches of the code. While testing any particular feature, any local branch can be deployed very well and tested whether that functionality is working fine without any glitches and hiccups. The interface is quite user friendly and quite intuitive and easy to use.  The amount of customisation provided on the interface is just right and appropiate.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
At crucial times of production deployment, some unknown issues crop up, which are very irritating and blocks the deployment. These unknown issues are intermittent and tough to debug.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
If you want to free developers from deployment activities, this tool is a wonderful tool to automate deployments and save much of their time.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
This software makes the deployment much easier by making continuous deployment and continuous integration available through pipelines. In this way, developers can invest more time creating or implementing complex business logic or improving user experience.

Jenkins is the one which helps in continuous delivery of work. If our work has any errors, the build will get failed and we can easily narrow down the error. It's customizable and highly secure even though it is open source.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Our work will be in the testing phase for few months and will be deployed in production. So when we deploy our work in testing using Jenkins and after months when we deploy in production if we have any error or issue, we can't able to check build we did for testing as it saves only recent builds.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Using Jenkins we can deploy plenty of work in single build. Sometimes we will be having lot of our code work or queries, we can't deploy them manually one by one. So Jenkins saves time and increases the productivity by deploying them in a single build.

all_reviews.review_title: Jenkins :  Review on my view point experience and usage
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
-> This is an open-source tool, so everyone can use it free of cost and learn this as well.
-> Jankins has a vast amount of plugins, and it's also free, so anyone can add any plugin required for creating their pipeline to job done. I have used many like Jacoco to check the code coverage, Junit for the test, Sonarqube for code analysis, etc.
-> Jankins has open-source community support so you can post your query and get a response sooner, which makes your work faster if you are stuck due to some issues.
-> Easy CI/CD integration will save you most of the time and make you faster available for build on-premises.
-> I Like the most is the SCM feature which is source code management using bit bucket, git, or any repository. If you set up auto-build once user pushes their code, then it will start developing a Build.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
-> Although I like all features of Jenkins, there are some that I faced when I was delivering my tasks :
1. It has many plugins, but sometimes, because not all plugins are updated as per current technology trends, they might not be compatible. For example, when I was using java 11 in my project and plugin support till java seven so it has wasted most of my time. Still, it was not valuable due to an incompatibility issue.
2. If you have too many pipelines jobs in the projects which perform the different tasks, then it is hard to manage all pipelines as the dashboard is not easily understandable due to the user interface of Jenkins.
3. When some issues occur due to plugins or any other reason, an error message is understandable or not human-readable language.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
Make sure plugins are available as per technology trends; otherwise, you need to find alternate solutions

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
-> Creating a pipeline of my project, including automation of build creation and deployment, so this CI/CD saved my time in the deployment process. Once I commit my code, SCM will fetch the code through the pipeline and then start to build and deploy on the server, which saves a lot of time, especially if you are working on Agile methodologies where each sprint you have some deployment and go-live of system.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins is a Java-based open-source server that is available for free. To accomplish continuous integration, a series of operations can be carried out in an automated way.
Jenkins can interact with most development, testing, and deployment systems thanks to hundreds of plugins. Moreover, all these plugins are also free to use.
We integrated Jenkins with Docker to generate docker image and deploy on Azure. Every time a single developer makes a contribution, the code is built.  We can then determine the commit that caused the build to fail.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
It is great to build and configure pipeline workflows for our code repositories, which run automatically for each code push.
It has excellent community support, and solutions can be found quickly for any problems faced.
It comes with a lot of useful plugins.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Configuring the build can be difficult sometimes, and error reporting is not apt as users have to go through logs every time.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Using Jenkins for my team as a CICD solution where developers use it to provide quick build to QA, and QA teams use the same to run Automation test cases.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins does almost everything for you right from building application till testing part of the app. It integrates with other tools as well and provides so many options for applications with different technology stacks. It gives you multiple options like freestyle job, pipelines, multibranch pipelines, maven jobs to choose. Also, installing your own instance for practice is pretty easy and straight forward.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
For a beginner, it can be difficult. There are so many plugins in Jenkins which are not maintained properly. Sometimes it restarts frequently which causes build interruptions.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
If you are trying to find a way to automate your process like building and deploying an application, go for this tool. It integrates with other tools as well like veracode and sonarqube to give you code quality checks as well. It has free versions which won't cost you. For big organizations, you can switch to Cloudbees Jenkins giving more features. It can be even hosted in a docker container which is very light weight.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins is a great CI/CD tool to automate your release process. I was onboarding and automating applications using Jenkins and deploying them to Cloud and on-premise servers.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins delivers seamless integration with others tools like Slack. You can get a message from Jenkins as soon as the build is over! Slack Notification plugin is awesome!

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins has a lot of plugins that are not that useful. Many of them are also no longer maintained.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
We use Jenkins as the main CI/CD in our project, we organize jobs with similar function into a Group, we create jobs for the build, compile, and unit test each time a developer checks-in their code to a specified branch and build a new version of artifact when having master branch commit. We add some additional plugin and create Jenkins jobs for run system test, automation test, and integration test automatically when having new commit to master and have jobs for deploy our new code to destination VMs on demand.

We chose Jenkins as it is simple and flexible but powerful to handle our CI/CD pipeline. It is popular and easy to find documentation and support from the community and easy to integrate with our source repository on Bitbucket. It also works well with our technology stack including Jmeter, Selenium, Java, Tomcat and AWS.

What do you like best about Jenkins?
Open source Product, open to integrating with a lot of the third parties, it's an easy system to manage all integration platform
Jenkins is open-source software that facilitates the continuous integration of source code thanks to its plugins and its modules which allows keeping 360 supervision of our application from development to production.
It is also presented as a toolbox with its integration logic. We can connect our deliverable with source code management software with deployment servers with Linux and windows system with servers to do automated tests also with the system to do performance tests
Serious to your pipeline system we can keep a global view on the execution of our source code with steps and also we can delegate some validation to groups or to a user
also, it can notify users in case of success or error via slack or email or another communication channel

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Update & Installation Plugins, User rights
This open-source openness allows everyone to develop what they need that's why we have a rich encyclopedia with plugins that we will never use also Jenkins has security issues that we need to each time read the new releases and update the current version
If we need to have a good performance we need to install lots of server slave to execute all jobs in parallel

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
Good Product for CI/CD

One platform to deploy & build multi projects and cross projects with deferent Programmation languages & deferent system

all_reviews.review_title: Want to Automate Your Pipeline? Jenkins is the Way to Go
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
First and foremost, if you are building any kind of Continuous Integration & Continuous Delivery pipeline, this is the tool to get it done. There are a few alternatives, but there is a reason this one is the most popular. It has thousands of plugins and a TON of opensource community support, and that is always great.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
The user interface is a bit funky, but hey it is written in Java, and we all know user interface is hard to execute in Java. There are much better languages for interfaces, but Java is still great. Beyond that, I love Jenkins.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
I am solving the problem of integrating my dev stages and my ops stages in my software development life cycle. I guess you can say I am resolving the issue of DevOps with the Jenkins tool.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Best part is that it can detect the changes made to git repo so everytime a change is checked in on a specific branch it can trigger the deployment job. We did setup for our QA folks and it helped a lot. It keeps our code stable and QA tested most of the time. Reducing the time people spend in the deployment.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins is very user friendly tool but still you have to know any of the scripting language to manage the job. It's not a deal breaker as this tool is mostly intended for devops and scripting is a basic mandatory skill for  devops.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
I would recommend using Jenkins if you want to boost your development and QA team productivity.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
CICD and QA Automation. Ultimate benefit is that we are always testing/ using latest changes and we don't have to stick with the legacy model of monthly deployments.

all_reviews.review_title: Jenkins - A way for Continuous integration
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins  tuns  very fast and it has very good variety of settings that helps in building the new project in very less time frame.
Jenkins is very easy to setup and configure and there are lot of plugins.

Moreover , the USP of this tools is that it has  for Linux as well as Windows platforms.

The support is really great,

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
In Jenkins there is no search functionality, which makes it difficult to search in case of multiple builds.
Jenkins  does not have any  feature for tracking job history. We are unable to restore jobs if we delete or update by mistake and this leads to rework.

When you are performing installation and if you get an error, then it is some what difficult to understand the issue.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
Jenkins has been used by us  for a long time. It is quite reliable CI tool.  You want to use for DEv and QA or you can use for DevOps. It will never disappoint you.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
We use Jenkins for  build management.  It is mostly used by the development and QA teams.

We use Jenkins  for both manual and automated builds projects.

It helps the developers to work together and create a  combined solution, such that  QA team can test it all at once. This saves a lot of repetition.

It also integrates with github which we are using for version control.

Jenkins is so pervasive in developer circles that everyone contributes to the open source projcet and that's what makers it great- For the people by the People!

all_reviews.review_title: Popularity wins - and the plugins are all over the place
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
The sheer amount of plugins available. The recognition by any company/product that has anything to do with builds and/or CI/CD, even if they don't like it or recommend something else, they always at least have heard of and have some documentation on integration with Jenkins because it'd be folly not to support it.  It's very versatile and can be configured so radically different in so many different ways that you're almost guarenteed to be able to mold it to suit your needs.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
A lot of the plugins are low quality, or very outdated/abandoned. The flexibility of Jenkins is also a double edged sword, you can have 2 different companies using Jenkins and they're both completely configured differently, nothing like each other. There's no real "standards",  everybody has a difference of opinion on the best way to configure/use Jenkins and they're all positive they're doing it the right way aka "Best Practices", which makes it very frustrating when you're trying to set it up or use it in your own company.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
Do a lot of research on "best practices" before implementing it. Don't just dive in because it's super easy to do so but then you'll find yourself locked into that particular way of doing things going forward.  Plan on if you want to use Pipeline, Jenkinsfile, or Freestyle. Try to stick with that project type as much/best as you can, get all developers to use the standards you layout whether they like it or not. Everyone will agree that even if they don't like it personally, they'll enjoy being able to read/understand each others Builds because it was done in a similar fashion.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Building the software.  Deploying the Software (CI/CD). Pushing artifacts to artifactory. Security Code scanning with Coverity (SAST). Open source scanning with Black Duck. Integrations with Gitlab, Bamboo, JIRA, Confluence, Slack, AWS and others.

review_question_answers.question: What do you like best about Jenkins?
review_question_answers.answer: The sheer amount of plugins available. The recognition by any company/product that has anything to do with builds and/or CI/CD, even if they don't like it or recommend something else, they always at least have heard of and have some documentation on integration with Jenkins because it'd be folly not to support it.  It's very versatile and can be configured so radically different in so many different ways that you're almost guarenteed to be able to mold it to suit your needs.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
In terms of configuration, Jenkins offers simplicity and straightforwardness. We can check errors even if our work is on progress and acquire built-in assistance from the software. With its wide range of plugins available, we can make it easy to integrate Jenkins with other programs and take advantage of the continuous delivery and integration along the way. It is open source, free and easy to use.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins lacks support for integrating and testing multiple services at once. That's essential functionality for a microservices environment. When we plan to invest in the overhead of multiple pipelines, Jenkins does a poor job of helping us develop next-generation microservices apps. There is no collaboration features as well.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
One of the most popular continuous integration tools available.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
I use Jenkins to build and test our software projects continuously. It makes easier for us to integrate changes to the project, and it makes easier for users to obtain a fresh build. I achieved successful continuous integration and delivery in software projects.

all_reviews.review_title: I found Jenkins the best tool for continuous integration and delivery.
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins allow to integrate with all major version control system like git even Subversion SVN and Mercurial.
Large community support gives it more leverage over other tools and organization love to use it.
Being open source Jenkins attract more developer and gain trust.
I have found Jenkins a very stable platform comparative to other platforms.
Jenkins is more extensible using plugins and its integration with version control systems, software development languages, software testing frameworks.
Jenkins provide customize log after running defined tests. In case build fails or any error occurs during integration log is great help to locate the error.
Jenkins is free to use, no coast to pay to use Jenkins but you need hosting to host Jenkins.
You can configure Jenkins according to development process your organization using or for specific project.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins require hosting server to run, that adds cost, if you are working with larger team you will need powerful expensive server.
You need to configure it before use, extra work is needed to configure and run on server.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
If your organization or project require more flexibility of configuration and customization then Jenkins would be best choice. For security sensitive project you will have full control over Jenkins. Use Jenkins for enterprise projects, for small projects you could go for Travis CI.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins is great tool for development task automation like automation of continuous integration, continuous delivery which save lot of our time, you just need to focus on actual development rather than testing and deployment.
There are other tools like Jenkins which can do automation of continuous integration and continuous delivery, even open source tools like Jenkins, but we choose Jenkins because of its large community support and its extensible through plugins and integration.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
What I loved about this software :
The execution of the test cases on a daily basis
Executing mobile and web test cases
Recover the automation code from git for the test execution
The high quality reports generated by jenkins, that contain the time exeuction, the passes and fails, screenshots of the failed steps and the exact code line where the test failed
Configuring the email list where the report is sent
The easiness of use when it comes to checking the report
The free Jenkins documentation online
On top of all, this amazing tool is free :D

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
It is very hard to create a Jenkins job for beginners

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
If you are in a continuous Integration environment, you cannot find a better and a more reliable tool for free.
Jenkins is simply the best.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
As a Software Quality Assurance and Automation, my main job after writing and automating the tests, is being able to run the tests daily.
When the test base exceeds ten test cases, it becomes difficult and time consuming to execute test cases daily.
That's why I use Jenkins, as it allows me to run my test cases daily, and the best part is that I can run mobile and web test cases, and test cases that combine the two. I created a jenkins job to execute the tests daily, and send me and to my team the execution report by email. The report contains all the passes and fails and screenshots of the failed test cases, the consumed time and the percentage of the passed and failed.
I simply couldn't find a better tool to execute automated test cases.

What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins is powerful tool for continuous integration and delivery while working with different module of project. we use it for code build, test automation and deploy as it provide all require plugin. we also
have integrated Jenkins with bitbucket, jira and slack that makes our job easy in project lifecycle.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
I have no serious dislike with jenkins which i think should share.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
Overall Jenkins is the best tool that reduce lot of our manual errors and help to automate lot of project stuff by providing various plugins. we commit the code to git and automatically jenkin build get triggered or we can also manually trigger that compile our whole code. we can also schedule to run our test automation jobs automatically with it. Viewing log is also easy as all action get tracked. After using it from last 2 years , there are no major negative point.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
1. Jenkins makes our jobs easy as there is no manual error while compiling the code.
2. Easily can create different jobs for different project module so we can track easily.
3. For test automation we can run different jobs parallel to get faster results and also
we can efficiently track them.
4. jenkins can be integrated with different tools like bitbucket, jira and slack etc to make
our job done smartly and efficiently.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
The UX is very old and not very user friendly, compared to modern and managed services like Travis and Circle CI.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Having a CI/CD pipeline is a must for enabling a DevOps culture and Jenkins has totally helped in that direction. The ability to use community written plugins is awesome and very helpful.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
The first and foremost thing about Jenkins is it is an opensource tool. Companies dont have to think about budgeting to get Jenkins into their space. Once it is in, the integration setup is quite easy and quick. It has an advantage of getting addons for integration with other tools. It can be accessed through url all over the network without having to install any client softwares to access it. Jenkins can pickup from a numerous source code management tools and send to build tools or any other specified deployment process automatically. It automates he CI/CD (Continous integration and continous deployment) pipeline from end to end.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Jenkins support with .Net as a source code seems to lack behind the tool Bamboo. Although it works well with Java as a code and we also use Terraform, the .Net guys always have a complaint about Jenkins integration.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
We have reduced the human intervention in the development process. The code from the developers is automatically pulled from Git and built through Maven and is automatically handed over to the testing team for the next process. It also helps us to keep a copy the build versions in the artifact repository. The automaton also made our environment error free by eliminating the human errors. We even push Terraform code using Jenkins to spinup the resources in AWS cloud platform. It integrates the orchestration tools seemlessly for performing the resource creation tasks.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
Jenkins is one of the best Continous development tools in the market. It can automatically run test jobs whenever you push your code to a repository. Hence easily,  issues can be identified and even the code can run for dependency errors on a remote machine. provides accurate build logs for a particular job with regular success/failure email notifications to concerned users. Jenkins can integrate with almost any external system used for developing applications which means that you worry less about your tooling and more about delivering good code.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
I haven't come across anything which I don't like about jenkins. However, UI can be improved a bit.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
I use Jenkins to provide continuous integration of application code and often use it for continuous deployment as well. Jenkins can watch source code repositories for changes and immediately pull that code and send it through a battery of steps designed to ensure that no problems were introduced into the code when it is integrated with other developer's code.

all_reviews.review_title: Good for continuous deployment for small companies
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Jenkins?
It is easy to break tasks into many jobs and chain them together. There are also many plugins for many platforms and if one is not available, you can always script them. It is also easy to integrate with many notification methods like email or webhooks for slack.

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
It is open source and so there are times when plugins have issues and they need to be fixed by others or you need to suggest a work around. The UI is not very attractive. Jenkins build uses servers and if the servers are less, load is more, and the build may take a long time to complete.

Recommendations to others considering Jenkins:
Don't forget to take the leap.

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Using it for building code and deployment. Automatically creates a build and posts to company managed Jenkins page.

Jenkins the most useful tool for integrating source code repositories with organizations infrastructure to enable seemless automated build delivery into any environment.
Test automation tools such as Selenium and UFT can be integrated with Jenkins so that build verification tests can be run unattended and overnight

Jenkins is quite flexible and a tool of choice for most who take the devops route; another important factor is that Jenkins can be integrated with any development platform and hence there is less concern on compatibility and extrernal restrictions

What do you dislike about Jenkins?
Only area of improvement is on the UX side where Jenkins can make the look and feel more intuitive

What problems is Jenkins solving and how is that benefiting you?
Jenkins was the primary solution platform for CI/CD.  Most applications on devops now are completely reliant on this tool to give the much needed flexibility
